awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Preventing Snow Accumulation and Facilitating Snow Removal
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of technology for the prevention of snow accumulation that can be adapted to various autonomous and modern vehicles to enable their safe operation in all weather conditions. This technology can contribute to reducing roadway fatalities and create additional jobs and economic opportunities in transportation industry. Enhancement in power generation efficiency of photovoltaic modules during winter using the proposed passive technology (i.e., the snowphobic coating) may contribute to reduction in the use of nonrenewable sources of energy, potentially addressing climate change. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a passive technology to enable an understanding of the interaction of snow (which is a mixture of ice, air, and water) with solid surfaces during snow removal processes. The proposed research may advance the snow-removal surface coatings beyond currently available superhydrophobic and icephobic coatings which only deal with interactions of the surface with a single phase of water   (i.e., only water or ice). The proposed coating will utilize fundamental understandings related to the composition of snow and its interaction with surfaces to provide durable coatings desirable for facilitating of snow removal under various environmental conditions. Finally, production and application of the proposed coatings are scalable, advancing the manufacture of low cost polymeric surfaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Snow accumulation on surfaces causes major safety and energy concerns for transportation systems, aviation, and energy sectors. For example, snow accumulation on photovoltaic modules reduces their power generation efficiency during winter. Another example is wet snow accumulation on visual sensors/navigators of autonomous vehicles (AVs) that increases possibility of accidents by obstructing the lenses of the sensors. Our team has developed active and passive methods to prevent/remove snow accumulation on various surfaces. Our technology includes a design that forms a controlled airstream on surfaces that prevents any snow accumulation on those surfaces. A sister technology is developed to facilitate snow removal from surfaces using a durable snowphobic coating that is distinguishable than currently-available icephobic coatings.

 

This NSF I-Corps enabled our team to pursue two activities:

 

-Collecting customer discovery data related to prevention of snow accumulation on camera lenses and sensors of autonomous vehicles (AVs). This led to an NSF PFI grant application which was denied but received very positive reviews. The team is currently working on submitting an NSF SBIR application for this project.

 

-A customer discovery that led to a successful prize application with DOE (American Made Solar Prize Round 6). The team was selected among 20 teams receiving $50k and advancing to the next round. In the next round the team was again selected among 10 finalists receiving $100k and $75k of voucher for Sandia's National Lab. The team was also selected for the Justice, Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion prize. The team competed in the final stage of the solar prize at RE+ Expo in Sep 2023 and despite not winning the grand prize received recognition and interests from over 100 companies in the solution offered for mitigation of snow accumulation on solar panels.
